The denominator is nonzero.

type: ∀ (self : ℚ), self.den ≠ 0
name: Rat.den_nz
docString: The denominator is nonzero.

For every prime number p in the natural numbers, the p-adic norm of the sum of two p-adic numbers is less than or equal to the maximum of their individual p-adic norms.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact p.Prime] (q r : ℚ_[p]), ‖q + r‖ ≤ max ‖q‖ ‖r‖
name: padicNormE.nonarchimedean
docString: For every prime number p in the natural numbers, the p-adic norm of the sum of two p-adic numbers is less than or equal to the maximum of their individual p-adic norms.

This theorem states that two positive natural numbers, `a` and `b`, are equal if and only if their p-adic valuations are equal for every prime number `p`. This means that for every prime number `p`, the highest power of `p` that divides `a` is the same as the highest power of `p` that divides `b`. Note that `a` and `b` must be non-zero for this theorem to apply.

type: ∀ (a b : ℕ), a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → (a = b ↔ ∀ (p : ℕ), p.Prime → padicValNat p a = padicValNat p b)
name: Nat.eq_iff_prime_padicValNat_eq
docString: This theorem states that two positive natural numbers, `a` and `b`, are equal if and only if their p-adic valuations are equal for every prime number `p`. This means that for every prime number `p`, the highest power of `p` that divides `a` is the same as the highest power of `p` that divides `b`. Note that `a` and `b` must be non-zero for this theorem to apply.

Two positive naturals are equal if their prime padic valuations are equal

type: ∀ (a b : ℕ), a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → (a = b ↔ ∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p → padicValNat p a = padicValNat p b)
name: Nat.eq_iff_prime_padicValNat_eq
docString: Two positive naturals are equal if their prime padic valuations are equal

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem, `Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19`, states that the integer 1 is not even. In the context of this theorem, a number is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers. However, there is no integer that, when doubled, equals 1, hence 1 is not considered even under this definition.

type: ∀ {α : Sort u_1} {a b : α}, (a = b) = (b = a)
name: Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19
docString: This theorem, `Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19`, states that the integer 1 is not even. In the context of this theorem, a number is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers. However, there is no integer that, when doubled, equals 1, hence 1 is not considered even under this definition.

Nonnegative real numbers.

type: Type
name: NNReal
docString: Nonnegative real numbers.

The sum over the reciprocals of the primes diverges.

type: ¬Summable (Set.indicator {p | Nat.Prime p} fun n => 1 / ↑n)
name: not_summable_one_div_on_primes
docString: The sum over the reciprocals of the primes diverges.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

name: Nat.dvd_right_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

A sum of finite numbers is still finite

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, (∀ a ∈ s, f a ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.sum s fun a => f a) < ⊤
name: ENNReal.sum_lt_top
docString: A sum of finite numbers is still finite

The real numbers are isomorphic to the quotient of Cauchy sequences on the rationals.

type: ℝ ≃ CauSeq.Completion.Cauchy abs

docString: The real numbers are isomorphic to the quotient of Cauchy sequences on the rationals.

Nonnegative rational numbers.

name: NNRat

The type of prime numbers

type: Type

The clifford algebra is graded by the even and odd parts.

type:
{R : Type u_1} →
  {M : Type u_2} →
    [inst : CommRing R] →
      [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] →
        [inst_2 : Module R M] → (Q : QuadraticForm R M) → GradedAlgebra (CliffordAlgebra.evenOdd Q)
name: CliffordAlgebra.gradedAlgebra
docString: The clifford algebra is graded by the even and odd parts.

The convolution of two even functions is also even.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u𝕜} {G : Type uG} {E : Type uE} {E' : Type uE'} {F : Type uF} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E'] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] {f : G → E} {g : G → E'} {x : G}
  [inst_3 : NontriviallyNormedField 𝕜] [inst_4 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E'] [inst_6 : NormedSpace 𝕜 F]
  (L : E →L[𝕜] E' →L[𝕜] F) [inst_7 : MeasurableSpace G] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure G} [inst_8 : NormedSpace ℝ F]
  [inst_9 : AddCommGroup G] [inst_10 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsAddLeftInvariant μ]
  [inst_11 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsNegInvariant μ] [inst_12 : MeasurableNeg G] [inst_13 : MeasurableAdd G],
  (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, f (-x) = f x) → (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, g (-x) = g x) → convolution f g L (-x) = convolution f g L x
name: convolution_neg_of_neg_eq
docString: The convolution of two even functions is also even.

Every finite convergent corresponds to a rational number.

type:
∀ {K : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField K] [inst_1 : FloorRing K] (v : K) (n : ℕ),
  ∃ q, GeneralizedContinuedFraction.convergents (GeneralizedContinuedFraction.of v) n = ↑q
name: GeneralizedContinuedFraction.exists_rat_eq_nth_convergent
docString: Every finite convergent corresponds to a rational number.

Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

type: ℕ+ → ℕ+ → Prop
name: PNat.Coprime
docString: Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

Rational numbers are dense in a linear ordered archimedean field.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace 𝕜] [inst_2 : OrderTopology 𝕜]
  [inst_3 : Archimedean 𝕜], DenseRange Rat.cast
name: Rat.denseRange_cast
docString: Rational numbers are dense in a linear ordered archimedean field.

The number of inequalities in the series

name: RelSeries.length

The numerator and denominator are coprime: it is in "reduced form".

type: ∀ (self : ℚ), Nat.Coprime (Int.natAbs self.num) self.den
name: Rat.reduced
docString: The numerator and denominator are coprime: it is in "reduced form".

Shows that the integer parts of the continued fraction are at least one.

type:
∀ {K : Type u_1} {v : K} {n : ℕ} [inst : LinearOrderedField K] [inst_1 : FloorRing K] {b : K},
  Stream'.Seq.get? (GeneralizedContinuedFraction.partialDenominators (GeneralizedContinuedFraction.of v)) n = some b →
    1 ≤ b
name: GeneralizedContinuedFraction.of_one_le_get?_part_denom
docString: Shows that the integer parts of the continued fraction are at least one.

The Mersenne numbers, 2^p - 1.

type: ℕ → ℕ
name: mersenne
docString: The Mersenne numbers, 2^p - 1.

If the p-adic valuation of a finite set of positive rationals is greater than a given rational
number, then the p-adic valuation of their sum is also greater than the same rational number.

type:
∀ {p j : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] {F : ℕ → ℚ} {S : Finset ℕ},
  S.Nonempty →
    (∀ i ∈ S, padicValRat p (F j) < padicValRat p (F i)) →
      (∀ (i : ℕ), 0 < F i) → padicValRat p (F j) < padicValRat p (Finset.sum S fun i => F i)
name: padicValRat.lt_sum_of_lt
docString:
If the p-adic valuation of a finite set of positive rationals is greater than a given rational
number, then the p-adic valuation of their sum is also greater than the same rational number.

The terms of the sequence are nonzero.

name: NumberField.Units.dirichletUnitTheorem.seq_ne_zero
docString: The terms of the sequence are nonzero.
